I came here with a friend in September when we were on vacation in Barcelona.  We decided to try the prix fixe tapas menu (you get to taste ~7 tapas, plus dessert, plus sangria as well as a welcome glass of cava for only 19 euros).  The cava sangria was absolutely delicious, light, and refreshing; however, if you want something a little stronger, then you should order something else, as my friend and I were barely buzzed after consuming a pitcher each.  The tapas came out very hurriedly; at some times, we had three different plates on our table.  The first three tapas included bread with tomato, a homemade salad, and peppers with small ham cubes.  The bread with tomato was a little bland and the salad was not particularly special, but the peppers were nicely seasoned and fresh-tasting.  After that, we were given a platter of cured meats, which was great as is expected of Spanish meat plates.  The next tapa was a blood sausage and chorizo combo.  The chorizo was very spicy (in a great way) and paired well with the blood sausage/rice.  Afterwards, they brought out an egg and potato casserole that was hearty and filling, with a duck foie flavoring that provided a deep richness to the plate.  The prawns were well-cooked and seasoned.  The dessert, the Catalan cream, was disappointing; it was overly sweet, and didn't have the right balance of temperatures/flavors that I expected.I would probably give the food a 3 overall; however, the fact that we got all that food, dessert, and cava sangria (which left us completely stuffed) for only 19 euros brings this to a 4.  It is a very reasonably priced restaurant, and the prix fixe tapas menu gives you a wide variety of interesting tapas to try.
